P(13, 8) = 13 \cdot (13-1) \cdot (13-2) \cdot \dots \cdot (13-8+1)= {5.18918\times 10^{7}} ways. You are choosing and arranging 8 out of 13 cookies. Order matters now.
{35 \choose 23}={8.34452\times 10^{8}} choices. You must switch between cookie type 12 times as you make your 23 cookies. The cookies are the stones; the switches between cookie types are the sticks.
13^{23} choices. You have 13 choices for the 1 cookie, 13 choices for the 2 cookie, and so on.

13^{23} - \left[{13 \choose 1}(13-1)^{23} - {13 \choose 2}(13-2)^{23} + \cdots - {13 \choose 13}0^{23} \right]={2.49879\times 10^{24}} choices. We must use PIE to remove all the ways in which one or more cookie type is not selected.

statement.p: What is the smallest number of moves required to transport 2 disks to another pillar?
What is the smallest number of moves required to transport 3 disks to another pillar?
What is the smallest number of moves required to transport 4 disks to another pillar?

To find the smallest number of moves required to transport 5 disks to another pillar, lets try to relate this task to the task of moving 4 disks. How many moves do each of the following tasks require?
Move the 4 smallest disks to the second pillar: moves.
Move the largest disk to the third pillar: moves.
Move the 4 smallest disks to the third pillar (on top of the largest disk): moves.
Therefore, the smallest number of moves required to move five disks is:

Generalize the last observation. Let a_n represent the smallest number of moves required to transport n disks from the start pillar to another pillar. Then a_{n-1} represents the number of moves required to transport n-1 disks to another pillar.
Give a formula for a_{n} in terms of a_{n-1}\text{.}
For the sequence with closed formula a_n = {n^{2}+5n+4}\text{,} find the term a_7\text{.}
Consider the sequence with recurrence relation a_n = a_{n-1} + 6 with initial term a_0 = 3\text{.} Find the term a_4\text{.}
Consider the sequence with recurrence relation a_n = 7\cdot a_{n-1} with initial term a_0 = 9\text{.} Find the term a_6\text{.}

Find the closed formula for each of the following sequences (a_n)_{n\ge 1} by relating them to a well known sequence. Assume the first term given is a_1\text{.}
-1, 2, 7, 14, 23, \ldots
a_n =
3, 5, 8, 12, 17, \ldots
a_n =
11, 16, 22, 29, 37, \ldots
a_n =
25, 121, 721, 5041, 40321, \ldots
a_n =

hint.p: Try adding or subtracting the same small number from each term to see if you recognize the sequence.

statement.p:
For each sequence given below, find a closed formula for a_n, the nth term of the sequence (assume the first terms here are always a_0) by relating it to another sequence for which you already know the formula.
0, 1, 3, 7, 15, 31, \ldots
a_n =
-1, 0, 7, 26, 63, 124, \ldots
a_n =
0, 3, 12, 27, 48, 75, \ldots
a_n =
1, 3, 8, 17, 32, 57, \ldots
a_n =

hint.p: Try adding, subtracting, or dividing each term by a constant to make the sequence more recognizable.
For part (d), try expressing the sequence as the sum of two well known sequences.

introduction.p: Explore the first sequence of dots from the Investigate! activity. We will let a_n represent the number of dots in figure n\text{.} The sequence starts 1, 5, 9,\ldots

statement.p: How many dots would you expect in the next two figures in the sequence?
How is the sequence growing? How many dots do you add to or multiply by to get the next figure?
Let a_n be the number of dots in figure n\text{.} Write a recursive definition for a_n\text{.}
Guess a closed formula for the number of dots in the nth figure.

introduction.p: Now look at the second sequence of dots from the Investigate! activity. We will let a_n represent the number of dots in figure n\text{.} The sequence starts 2, 6, 18,\ldots

statement.p: How many dots would you expect in the next two figures in the sequence?
How is the sequence growing? How many dots do you add to or multiply by to get the next figure?
Let a_n be the number of dots in figure n\text{.} Write a recursive definition for a_n\text{.}
Guess a closed formula for the number of dots in the nth figure.

introduction.p: Now look at the third sequence of dots from the Investigate! activity. We will let a_n represent the number of dots in figure n\text{.} The sequence starts 1, 3, 6, 10,\ldots

statement.p: How many dots would you expect in the next two figures in the sequence?
Let a_n be the number of dots in figure n\text{.} Write a recursive definition for a_n\text{.}
Guess a closed formula for the number of dots in the nth figure.

introduction.p: Consider the recurrence relation a_n = a_{n-1} + 7\text{.}

statement.p: Find the first five terms of the sequence defined by the recurrence relation and initial condition a_0 = 17\text{.}
Find the closed formula for the sequence defined by the recurrence relation and initial condition a_0 = 17\text{.}
Find the first five terms of another sequence, also defined by the same recurrence relation but this time with initial condition a_0 = 1\text{.}
Find the closed formula for this second sequence.

introduction.p: Consider the recurrence relation a_n = 7a_{n-1}\text{.}

statement.p: Find the first five terms of the sequence defined by the recurrence relation and initial condition a_0 = 10\text{.}
Find the closed formula for the sequence defined by the recurrence relation and initial condition a_0 = 10\text{.}
Find the first five terms of another sequence, also defined by the same recurrence relation but this time with initial condition a_0 = 17\text{.}
Find the closed formula for this second sequence.
Find a closed formula for the sequence that starts 3, {27}, {243}, {2187}, {19683},\ldots\text{.} Assume a_0 = 3\text{.}
Find a closed formula for the sequence that starts 16, {26}, {36}, {46}, {56},\ldots\text{.} Assume a_0 = 16\text{.}

introduction.p: Consider the sequence that starts 1, 7, 13, 19, 25,\ldots where a_0 = 1\text{.}

statement.p: Which of the following could be a recursive definition for the sequence?

li.p: None of the above

statement.p: Find the closed formula for the sequence.
Is 3007 a term of the sequence?
Your summer job pays you $1000 per week, with a raise of $50 per week as a bonus for not being a quitter. How much will you make in the 10th week?
Your sisters summer job pays her $1000 per week, with a raise of 5% per week as a bonus for not being a quitter. How much will she make in the 10th week?
Find x and y such that 125, x, y, 1 is part of an arithmetic sequence.
x = , y =
Then find x and y so that the sequence is part of a geometric sequence.
x = , y =
(Warning: x and y might not be integers.)

solution.p: For arithmetic: x = 83.6666666666667\text{,} y = 42.3333333333333\text{.} For the arithmetic sequence, we know 125 + d = x\text{,} x + d = y\text{,} and y + d = 1\text{.} In other words, 125 + 3d = 1 so d = (-41.3333333333333)/3\text{.} For geometric: x = {25} and y = {5}\text{.} Similarly we can find the common ratio for the geometric sequence by solving 125\cdot r^3 = 1 for r\text{.}

statement.p: Find x and y such that 4, x, y, 31 is part of an arithmetic sequence.
x = , y =
Then find x and y so that the sequence is part of a geometric sequence.
x = , y =
(Warning: x and y might not be integers.)

solution.p: For arithmetic: x = 13 \text{,} y = 22 \text{.} We know that 4 + d = x\text{,} x + d = y\text{,} and y + d = 31\text{.} In other words, 4 + 3d = 31 so d = (27)/3\text{.}
For geometric: x = {7.91578} and y = {15.6649}\text{.} We can find the common ratio for the geometric sequence by solving 4\cdot r^3 = 31 for r\text{.}

introduction.p: While wandering the halls of the math department, you find yourself staring at the captivating artwork shown below.

image.shortdescription: A square array of dots with L-shaped lines separating collections of odd numbers of dots.

statement.p: How many dots are in the figure?
The dots form a by square, for a total of dots.
We can also compute the total number of dots by summing each hook region, from smallest to largest:
Yet another way to calculate the total number of dots is to group the terms of this sum.
Since there are three pairs of sums, the total is 3 \cdot = .
If we generalize the diagram, so it has n hooks, how many dots will be in the largest hook?
How many dots will be in the second largest hook?
What will the sum of the smallest and largest hooks be?
What will the sum of the second smallest and second largest hooks be?
If we continue adding pairs of hooks (next smallest plus next largest), how many pairs will we have?
Multiplying then, the total number of dots will be: .

hint.p: Lets assume that n is even. If it wasnt, then there would be a single middle hook that isnt added to anything, but this is counteracted by the fact that n/2 would count a half hook sum.

statement.p: Consider the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts 5, 10, 15, 20, \ldots\text{.}

li.p: What is the next term in the sequence?
Find a formula for the nth term of this sequence.
Find the sum of the first 100 terms of the sequence: \sum_{k=0}^{99}a_k\text{.}
25\text{,} which is 20+5\text{.}
The sequence is arithmetic, with a_0 = 5 and constant difference 5, so a_n = 5 + 5n\text{.}
25250\text{.} We want 5 + 15 + \cdots + 500\text{.} Reverse and add to get 100 sums of 505, a total of 50500, which is twice the sum we are looking for.

statement.p: Consider the sum 9 + 14 + 19 + 24 + \cdots + 229\text{.}

li.p: How many terms (summands) are in the sum?
Compute the sum using a technique discussed in this section.

statement.p: Consider the sequence -18, -6, 6, 18, \ldots, 12n + 6\text{.}

li.p: How many terms are there in the sequence? Your answer will be in terms of n\text{.}
What is the second-to-last term?
Find the sum of all the terms in the sequence, in terms of n\text{.}
{n-\left(-2\right)+1} terms, since to get -18 using the formula 12n+6 we must use n=-2\text{.}
12n - 6\text{,} which is 12 less than 12n+6 (or plug in n-1 for n).
\frac{(12n - 12)*({n-\left(-2\right)+1})}{2}\text{.} Reverse and add. Each sum gives the constant 12n - 12, and there are {n-\left(-2\right)+1} terms.

statement.p: Find 2 + 8 + 14 + 20+ \cdots + 1808 using a technique from this section.

solution.p: 273310\text{.} If we take a_0 = 2\text{,} the terms of the sum are an arithmetic sequence with closed formula a_n = 2+6n\text{.} Then 1808 = a_{301}\text{,} for a total of 302 terms in the sum. Reverse and add to get 302 identical 1810 terms, which is twice the total we seek. 1810\cdot 302/2 = 273310.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts,

solution.p: a_n = {n^{2}+8n}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} Since a_0 = 0\text{,} we know c= 0\text{.} So just solve the system
to find a = 1 and b = 8.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts,

solution.p: a_n = {n^{2}+4n-1}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} Since a_0 = {-1}, we know c= {-1}\text{.} So just solve the system
to find a = {1} and b = {4}.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 0} which starts,

solution.p: a_n = {2n^{3}-2n+5}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a cubic because the third differences are constant. So a_n = an^3 + bn^2 + cn + d\text{.} Since a_0 = {5}, we know d= {5}\text{.} So just solve the system
to find a = {2}, b = 0, and c = {-2}.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{9, 43, 117, 243, 433}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {2n^{3}+8n^{2}-4n+3}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a cubic because the third differences are constant. So a_n = an^3 + bn^2 + cn + d\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {3}, so we know d= {3}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {2}, b = {8}, and c = {-4}.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{7, 32, 87, 184, 335}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {2n^{3}+3n^{2}+2n}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a cubic because the third differences are constant. So a_n = an^3 + bn^2 + cn + d\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {0}, so we know d= {0}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {2}, b = {3}, and c = {2}.

introduction.p: Consider the recurrence relation
Since the nth term is given as a combination of the two previous terms, we will need two initial terms to determine the sequence. Different initial terms will give different sequences.

statement.p: What sequence do you get if the initial conditions are a_0 = 1\text{,} a_1 = 2\text{?} Give the first five terms (including 1 and 2).
Based on the first few terms, what is a closed formula for this sequence?
What sequence do you get if the initial conditions are a_0 = 1\text{,} a_1 = 3\text{?} Give the first five terms.
Based on the first few terms, what is a closed formula for this sequence?
What sequence do you get if the initial conditions are a_0 = 2\text{,} a_1 = 5\text{?} Give the first five terms.
Based on the first few terms, what is a closed formula for this sequence?

hint.p: How do the terms in this sequence relate to the terms in the previous two sequences?

statement.p: Find 6 + 30 + 150 + \cdots + 6\cdot 5^{19}\text{.}

solution.p: \frac{6\cdot 5^{20}-6}{4}\text{.} Let the sum be S\text{,} and compute 5S - S = 4S\text{,} which causes terms except 6 and 6\cdot 5^{20} to cancel. Then solve for S\text{.}

statement.p: Solve the recurrence relation a_n = a_{n-1} + 2^n with a_0 = -2\text{.}

hint.p: Use telescoping or iteration.

solution.p: a_n = -4 + 2^{n+1}\text{.} We should use telescoping or iteration here. For example, telescoping gives

p.me: \begin{aligned} a_1 - a_0 \amp = 2^1\\ a_2 - a_1 \amp = 2^2\\ a_3 - a_2 \amp = 2^3\\ \vdots\amp \vdots \\ a_n - a_{n-1} \amp = 2^n \end{aligned}

solution.p: which sums to a_n - a_0 = 2^{n+1} - 2 (using the multiply-shift-subtract technique for the geometric series on the right-hand side). Substituting a_0 =-2 and solving for a_n completes the solution.

statement.p: Find the solution to the recurrence relation a_n = 2a_{n-1} + 24a_{n-2} with initial terms a_0 = {2} and a_1 = {2}\text{.}

solution.p: By the characteristic root technique. a_n = {\left(-4\right)^{n}+6^{n}}\text{.}

statement.p: Find the solution to the recurrence relation a_n = a_{n-1} + 2a_{n-2} with initial terms a_0 = {2} and a_1 = {1}\text{.}
Find the solution to the recurrence relation b_n = b_{n-1} + 2b_{n-2} with initial terms b_0 = 9 and b_1 = {14}\text{.}

solution.p: The characteristic roots for both sequences are -1 and 2 (since the two sequences have the same recurrence relation, they have the same characteristic roots). Solving for coefficients in each case gives the closed formulas. We have a_n = {\left(-1\right)^{n}+2^{n}} and b_n = {\left({\frac{4}{3}}\right)\mathopen{}\left(-1\right)^{n}+\left({\frac{23}{3}}\right)\cdot 2^{n}}.

statement.p: Find the solution to the recurrence relation a_n = a_{n-1} + 2a_{n-2} with initial terms a_0 = 4 and a_1 = 17\text{.}

solution.p: By the characteristic root technique. a_n = {7\cdot 2^{n}-3\mathopen{}\left(-1\right)^{n}}\text{.}

introduction.p: Consider the following puzzle:

You have a rectangular chocolate bar, made up of n identical squares of chocolate. You can take such a bar and break it along any row or column. How many times will you have to break the bar to reduce it to n single chocolate squares?
At first, this question might seem impossible. Perhaps we meant to ask for the smallest number of breaks needed. Lets investigate.

statement.p: Suppose you started with a 1\times 3 bar. How many breaks would you need to reduce it to single squares?
If you had a 1\times 4 bar, how many breaks are required?

If you had 4 squares arranged in a 2\times 2 square, your first break would require you to break the chocolate into two 1 \times 2 bars. Then each of these would require more break(s), for a total of breaks to go from the 2\times 2 to single squares.
A 6-square bar could either be a 1 \times 6 bar, requiring breaks, or a 2 \times 3 bar.

There are two ways to proceed now.
Break the bar into two 1 \times 3 bars, each requiring more breaks, for a total of breaks.
Break the bar into a 1\times 2 bar and a 2 \times 2 bar. The 1 \times 2 bar takes more break(s) and the 2 \times 2 bar takes more break(s), for a total of breaks.
Based on the above data, what should our conjecture be for the number of breaks to reduce an n-square bar to single squares, in terms of n\text{?}
It will take breaks to reduce an n-square bar to single squares.

Do we believe this? Suppose you used one break to reduce the bar into two smaller bars, with a and b squares respectively. If the conjecture is correct, how many more breaks will it take to reduce the size a bar?
How many more breaks will it take to reduce the size b bar?
How many breaks is this all together, in terms of a and b\text{,} including the initial break?
But what is a+b\text{?} We got a and b by breaking the n squares in two pieces, so a+b =. This gives us a total number of breaks as .
Find 7 + 13 + 19+ \cdots + 1243\text{.}
Consider the sequence 28, 38, 48, 58, \ldots, 10n - 2\text{.}

li.p: How many terms are there in the sequence?
What is the second-to-last term?
Find the sum of all the terms in the sequence.
{n-3} terms.

statement.p: Consider the sequence given by a_n = 6\cdot 5^{n-1}\text{.}

li.p: Find the first 4 terms of the sequence.
What sort of sequence is this?
arithmetic
geometric
neither
Find the sum of the first 22 terms. That is, compute \sum_{k=1}^{22}a_k\text{.}
6, 30, 150, 750, \ldots The sequence is geometric.

statement.p: Use polynomial fitting to find the formula for the nth term of the sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts,
{11, 22, 35, 50, 67}, \ldots Note the first term above is a_1, not a_0.

solution.p: a_n = {n^{2}+8n+2}\text{.} Here we know that we are looking for a quadratic because the second differences are constant. So a_n = an^2 + bn + c\text{.} We can work backwards to find that a_0 = {2}, so we know c= {2}\text{.} Then solve the system,
to find a = {1} and b = {8}.

statement.p: The sequence (a_n)_{n \ge 1} starts -1, 0, 2, 5, 9, 14\ldots and has closed formula
Use this fact to find a closed formula for the sequence (b_n)_{n \ge 1} which starts 4, 10, 18, 28, 40, \ldots\text{.}

solution.p: The sequence is 4, 9, {89}, {269}, {2049}, \ldots. It has closed formula a_n = {\left({\frac{11}{9}}\right)\mathopen{}\left(-4\right)^{n}+\left({\frac{25}{9}}\right)\cdot 5^{n}}, using the characteristic root technique.

The sequence is 5, 7, {111}, {459}, {3375}, \ldots. It has closed formula a_n = {\left({\frac{23}{9}}\right)\mathopen{}\left(-3\right)^{n}+\left({\frac{22}{9}}\right)\cdot 6^{n}}, using the characteristic root technique.

statement.p: A = {\left\{2,4,5,6,7\right\}}\text{ and } B = {\left\{2,4,5,6,8\right\}} Find each of the following sets.
Your answers should include the curly braces

li.p: A \cup B = {\left\{2,4,5,6,7,8\right\}}\text{.} It includes everything that is in A or B or both.
A \cap B = {\left\{2,4,5,6\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything that is in both A and B\text{.}
A \setminus B = {\left\{7\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything that is in A except anything that is also in B\text{.} We could also have written this set as A \cap \bar{B}\text{.}

B \setminus A = {\left\{8\right\}}\text{.} It contains everything in B except anything that is also in A\text{.} Another way to write this is B \cap \bar{A}\text{.} Note that A \setminus B \ne B \setminus A\text{.}

This is the set \{3, 4, 5, \ldots\} since we need each element to be a natural number whose square is at least 3 more than 4. Since 3^2 - 3 = 6 but 2^2 - 3 = 1 we see that the first such natural number is 3.
We get the same set as the previous part, and the smallest non-negative number for which n^2 - 7 is a natural number is 3.
Note that if we didnt specify n \ge 0 by saying that n \in \mathbb N then any integer less than -3 would also be in the set, so there would not be a least element.

This is the set \{4, 5, 8, 13, \ldots\}\text{,} namely the set of numbers that are the result of squaring and adding 4 to a natural number. (0^2 + 4 = 4\text{,} 1^2 + 4 = 5\text{,} 2^2 + 4 = 8 and so on.) Thus the least element of the set is 4.

Now we are looking for natural numbers that are equal to taking some natural number, squaring it and adding 4. That is, \{4, 5, 8, 13, \ldots\}\text{,} the same set as the previous part. So again, the least element is 4.

solution.p: The set of largest size that is a subset of both A \text{ and } B is the intersection of A \text{ and } B \text{,} A \cap B = {\left\{8\right\}}\text{.}

statement.p: Find a set of smallest possible size that has both {4,6,7,9} and {5,6,7,9,10} as subsets.

Let A = \{n \in \mathbb{N} : 39 \le n \lt 55\} and B = \{n \in \mathbb{N} : 16 \lt n \le 44\}\text{.} Suppose C is a set such that C \subseteq A and C \subseteq B\text{.} What is the largest possible cardinality of C\text{?}
Let A = {\left\{1,4,7,12,14\right\}} and B = {\left\{1,4,14\right\}}\text{.} How many sets C have the property that C \subseteq A and B \subseteq C\text{.}

hint.p: You should be able to write all of them out. Dont forget A and B\text{,} which are also candidates for C\text{.}

solution.p: There will be exactly 4 such sets: {\left\{1,4,14\right\}}\text{,}{\left\{1,4,12,14\right\}}\text{,} {\left\{1,4,7,14\right\}}\text{,} and {\left\{1,4,7,12,14\right\}}\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = {\left\{2,3,4,5,6\right\}}\text{,} B = {\left\{4,5,6,7,8\right\}}\text{,} and C = {\left\{3,6,8\right\}}\text{.}

li.p: Find A \cap B\text{.}
Find A \cup B\text{.}
Find A \setminus B\text{.}
Find A \cap \overline{(B \cup C)}\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = \{1,2,\ldots, 9\}\text{.} How many subsets of A contain exactly one element (i.e., how many singleton subsets are there)?
How many doubleton subsets (containing exactly two elements) are there?

hint.p: Write these out, or at least start to and look for a pattern.

solution.p: Each of the 9 elements can be in a singleton set, so there are 9 of these.

To count the number of doubletons, not that there are 8 sets that include 1, and then 7 sets that include 2 and not 1, and then 6 that include 3 and not 1 or 2, and so on. So you can find 36 by summing the numbers from 1 to 8.

statement.p:
Let A = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}\text{.} Suppose B is a set with |B| = 5\text{.}
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cup B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \cap B|\text{?} Explain.
What are the smallest and largest possible values of |A \times B|\text{?} Explain.
Consider the function f:\{1,2,3,4,5\} \to \{1,2,3,4,5\} given by

li.p: Find f(4).
Find a n in the domain such that f(n) = 4\text{.}
Find an element n of the domain such that f(n) = n\text{.}
Find an element of the codomain that is not in the range.
f(4) = 2\text{,} since 2 is the number below 4 in the two-line notation.
Such an n is n= 3\text{,} since f(3) = 4\text{.} Note that 3 is above a 4 in the notation.
n = 1 has this property. We say that 1 is a fixed point of f\text{.} Not all functions have such a point.
Such an element is 3 (in fact, that is the only element in the codomain that is not in the range). In other words, 3 is not the image of any element under f\text{;} nothing is sent to 3.

statement.p: The following functions all have \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace as both their domain and codomain. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.m: f(x) = \begin{cases} x \amp \text{ if } x \lt 3 \\ x-2 \amp \text{ if } x \ge 3 \end{cases}
f(x) = \begin{cases} 3-x \amp \text{ if } x \lt 3 \\ x \amp \text{ if } x \ge 3 \end{cases}

hint.p: Since the domain and codomain are the same size, is it possible for a function to be injective but not surjective, or surjective but not injective?

statement.p: Consider the following functions f: \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace \to \lbrace 1,2,3\rbrace. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.

p.m: f(x) = \begin{cases} x \amp \text{ if } x \lt 4 \\ 6-x \amp \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{cases}

statement.p: Consider the following functions f: \lbrace 1,2,3,4\rbrace \to \lbrace 1,2,3,4,5\rbrace. For each, determine whether it is (only) injective, (only) surjective, bijective, or neither injective nor surjective.
Write out all functions f: \{1,2,3,4\} \to \{a,b\} (using two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are surjective?
How many are injective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 16 different functions. None of the functions are injective. Exactly 14 of the functions are surjective (there are 2 that are not: those that send everything to a or everything to b). No functions are both (since no functions here are injective).

statement.p: Write out all function f: \{1,2\} \to \{a,b,c,d\} (in two-line notation).
How many functions are there?
How many are surjective?
How many are injective?
How many are bijective?

solution.p: There are 16 functions: you have a choice of four outputs for f(1)\text{,} and for each, you have four choices for the output f(2)\text{.} Of these functions, 12 are injective, 0 are surjective, and 0 are both (i.e., bijective):

p.me: f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{a\amp a} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{b \amp b} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{c \amp c} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{d \amp d}
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{a\amp b} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{a \amp c} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{a \amp d} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{b \amp c}
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{b \amp a} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{c \amp a} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{d \amp a} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{c \amp b}
f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{b \amp d} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{d \amp b} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{c \amp d} \quad f = \twoline{1 \amp 2}{d \amp c}

introduction.p: Let X = \{n \in \N \st 0 \le n \le 999\} be the set of all numbers with three or fewer digits. Define the function f:X \to \N by f(abc) = a+b+c\text{,} where a\text{,} b\text{,} and c are the digits of the number in X (write numbers less than 100 with leading 0s to make them three digits). In other words, f returns the sum of the digits of its input. For example, f(253) = 2 + 5 + 3 = 10\text{.}

statement.p: Let A = \{n \in X \st 306 \le x \le 323\}\text{.} Find f(A)\text{.}
Find f\inv(\{1,3\})\text{.}
Find f\inv(2)\text{.}
Find f\inv(139)\text{.}
